# Joomla/Database Package version 1.7.1

Joomla Database Package

## The Joomla\Database\Query\PreparableInterface Interface

Joomla Database Query Preparable Interface.

Adds bind/unbind methods as well as a getBounded() method
to retrieve the stored bounded variables on demand prior to
query execution.

### Methods

#### `Joomla\Database\Query\PreparableInterface::bind`

Add a variable to an internal array that will be bound to a prepared SQL statement before query execution. Also

removes a variable that has been bounded from the internal bounded array when the passed in value is null.

##### Signature

```php
abstract public Joomla\Database\Query\PreparableInterface::bind ( [ string|int $key = null [, mixed $value = null [, int $dataType = 2 [, int $length = 0 [, array $driverOptions = [] ]]]]] ) : Joomla\Database\Query\PreparableInterface
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `key` | `string` or `int` | The key that will be used in your SQL query to reference the value. Usually of  the form ':key', but can also be an integer. Defaults to `null`. |
| `value` | `mixed` | The value that will be bound. The value is passed by reference to support output  parameters such as those possible with stored procedures. Defaults to `null`. |
| `dataType` | `int` | Constant corresponding to a SQL datatype. Defaults to `2`. |
| `length` | `int` | The length of the variable. Usually required for OUTPUT parameters. Defaults to `0`. |
| `driverOptions` | `array` | Optional driver options to be used. Defaults to `[]`. |

##### Return Values

`Joomla\Database\Query\PreparableInterface` 

##### Errors/Exceptions

No errors or exceptions are thrown.

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.
 
```php
/**
 * Add a variable to an internal array that will be bound to a prepared SQL statement before query execution. Also
 * removes a variable that has been bounded from the internal bounded array when the passed in value is null.
 *
 * @param   string|integer  $key            The key that will be used in your SQL query to reference the value. Usually of
 *                                          the form ':key', but can also be an integer.
 * @param   mixed           $value          The value that will be bound. The value is passed by reference to support output
 *                                          parameters such as those possible with stored procedures.
 * @param   integer         $dataType       Constant corresponding to a SQL datatype.
 * @param   integer         $length         The length of the variable. Usually required for OUTPUT parameters.
 * @param   array           $driverOptions  Optional driver options to be used.
 *
 * @return  PreparableInterface
 *
 * @since   1.0
 */
abstract public function bind( $key = null, mixed $value = null, int $dataType = 2, int $length = 0, array $driverOptions = []) : Joomla\Database\Query\PreparableInterface;
```
#### `Joomla\Database\Query\PreparableInterface::getBounded`

Retrieves the bound parameters array when key is null and returns it by reference. If a key is provided then that item is

returned.

##### Signature

```php
abstract public Joomla\Database\Query\PreparableInterface::getBounded ( [ mixed $key = null ] ) : mixed
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `key` | `mixed` | The bounded variable key to retrieve. Defaults to `null`. |

##### Return Values

`mixed` 

##### Errors/Exceptions

No errors or exceptions are thrown.

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.
 
```php
/**
 * Retrieves the bound parameters array when key is null and returns it by reference. If a key is provided then that item is
 * returned.
 *
 * @param   mixed  $key  The bounded variable key to retrieve.
 *
 * @return  mixed
 *
 * @since   1.0
 */
abstract public function getBounded(mixed $key = null) : mixed;
```

## The Joomla\Database\Query\LimitableInterface Interface

Joomla Database Query LimitableInterface.

Adds bind/unbind methods as well as a getBounded() method
to retrieve the stored bounded variables on demand prior to
query execution.

### Methods

#### `Joomla\Database\Query\LimitableInterface::processLimit`

Modify a query already in string format with the needed

additions to make the query limited to a particular number of
results, or start at a particular offset. This method is used
automatically by the __toString() method if it detects that the
query implements the LimitableInterface.

##### Signature

```php
abstract public Joomla\Database\Query\LimitableInterface::processLimit ( string $query, int $limit [, int $offset = 0 ] ) : string
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `query` | `string` | The query in string format |
| `limit` | `int` | The limit for the result set |
| `offset` | `int` | The offset for the result set Defaults to `0`. |

##### Return Values

`string` 

##### Errors/Exceptions

No errors or exceptions are thrown.

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.
 
```php
/**
 * Modify a query already in string format with the needed
 * additions to make the query limited to a particular number of
 * results, or start at a particular offset. This method is used
 * automatically by the __toString() method if it detects that the
 * query implements the LimitableInterface.
 *
 * @param   string   $query   The query in string format
 * @param   integer  $limit   The limit for the result set
 * @param   integer  $offset  The offset for the result set
 *
 * @return  string
 *
 * @since   1.0
 */
abstract public function processLimit(string $query, int $limit, int $offset = 0) : string;
```
#### `Joomla\Database\Query\LimitableInterface::setLimit`

Sets the offset and limit for the result set, if the database driver supports it.

Usage:
$query->setLimit(100, 0); (retrieve 100 rows, starting at first record)
$query->setLimit(50, 50); (retrieve 50 rows, starting at 50th record)

##### Signature

```php
abstract public Joomla\Database\Query\LimitableInterface::setLimit ( [ int $limit = 0 [, int $offset = 0 ]] ) : Joomla\Database\Query\LimitableInterface
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `limit` | `int` | The limit for the result set Defaults to `0`. |
| `offset` | `int` | The offset for the result set Defaults to `0`. |

##### Return Values

`Joomla\Database\Query\LimitableInterface` Returns this object to allow chaining.

##### Errors/Exceptions

No errors or exceptions are thrown.

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.
 
```php
/**
 * Sets the offset and limit for the result set, if the database driver supports it.
 *
 * Usage:
 * $query->setLimit(100, 0); (retrieve 100 rows, starting at first record)
 * $query->setLimit(50, 50); (retrieve 50 rows, starting at 50th record)
 *
 * @param   integer  $limit   The limit for the result set
 * @param   integer  $offset  The offset for the result set
 *
 * @return  LimitableInterface  Returns this object to allow chaining.
 *
 * @since   1.0
 */
abstract public function setLimit(int $limit = 0, int $offset = 0) : Joomla\Database\Query\LimitableInterface;
```

#### `Joomla\Database\Pdo\PdoQuery::call`

Add a single column, or array of columns to the CALL clause of the query.

Note that you must not mix insert, update, delete and select method calls when building a query.
The call method can, however, be called multiple times in the same query.

Usage:
$query->call('a.*')->call('b.id');
$query->call(array('a.*', 'b.id'));

#### `Joomla\Database\Pdo\PdoQuery::format`

Find and replace sprintf-like tokens in a format string.

Each token takes one of the following forms:
%%       - A literal percent character.
%[t]     - Where [t] is a type specifier.
%[n]$[x] - Where [n] is an argument specifier and [t] is a type specifier.

Types:
a - Numeric: Replacement text is coerced to a numeric type but not quoted or escaped.
e - Escape: Replacement text is passed to $this->escape().
E - Escape (extra): Replacement text is passed to $this->escape() with true as the second argument.
n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
q - Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quote().
Q - Quote (no escape): Replacement text is passed to $this->quote() with false as the second argument.
r - Raw: Replacement text is used as-is. (Be careful)

Date Types:
- Replacement text automatically quoted (use uppercase for Name Quote).
- Replacement text should be a string in date format or name of a date column.
y/Y - Year
m/M - Month
d/D - Day
h/H - Hour
i/I - Minute
s/S - Second

Invariable Types:
- Takes no argument.
- Argument index not incremented.
t - Replacement text is the result of $this->currentTimestamp().
z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(false).
Z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(true).

Usage:
$query->format('SELECT %1$n FROM %2$n WHERE %3$n = %4$a', 'foo', '#__foo', 'bar', 1);
Returns: SELECT `foo` FROM `#__foo` WHERE `bar` = 1

Notes:
The argument specifier is optional but recommended for clarity.
The argument index used for unspecified tokens is incremented only when used.

##### Signature

```php
public Joomla\Database\Pdo\PdoQuery::format ( string $format  ) : string
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `format` | `string` | The formatting string. |

##### Return Values

`string` Returns a string produced according to the formatting string.

##### Errors/Exceptions

No errors or exceptions are thrown.

##### Examples

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.

#### `Joomla\Database\Pdo\PdoDriver::getInstance`

Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.

There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.

Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.

##### Signature

```php
public static Joomla\Database\Pdo\PdoDriver::getInstance ( [ array $options = [] ] ) : Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `options` | `array` | Parameters to be passed to the database driver. Defaults to `[]`. |

##### Return Values

`Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver` A database object.

##### Errors/Exceptions

Throws RuntimeException <br />

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.

```php
 * DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
 * be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.
 *
 * Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
 * passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.
 *
 * @param   array  $options  Parameters to be passed to the database driver.

 * @return  DatabaseDriver  A database object.
```

#### `Joomla\Database\Mysql\MysqlDriver::getInstance`

Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.

There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.

Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.

##### Signature

```php
public static Joomla\Database\Mysql\MysqlDriver::getInstance ( [ array $options = [] ] ) : Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `options` | `array` | Parameters to be passed to the database driver. Defaults to `[]`. |

##### Return Values

`Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver` A database object.

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.

```php
 * be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.
 *
 * Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
```

#### `Joomla\Database\Mysql\MysqlQuery::format`

Find and replace sprintf-like tokens in a format string.

Each token takes one of the following forms:
%%       - A literal percent character.
%[t]     - Where [t] is a type specifier.
%[n]$[x] - Where [n] is an argument specifier and [t] is a type specifier.

Types:
a - Numeric: Replacement text is coerced to a numeric type but not quoted or escaped.
e - Escape: Replacement text is passed to $this->escape().
E - Escape (extra): Replacement text is passed to $this->escape() with true as the second argument.
n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
q - Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quote().
Q - Quote (no escape): Replacement text is passed to $this->quote() with false as the second argument.
r - Raw: Replacement text is used as-is. (Be careful)

Date Types:
- Replacement text automatically quoted (use uppercase for Name Quote).
- Replacement text should be a string in date format or name of a date column.
y/Y - Year
m/M - Month
d/D - Day
h/H - Hour
i/I - Minute
s/S - Second

Invariable Types:
- Takes no argument.
- Argument index not incremented.
t - Replacement text is the result of $this->currentTimestamp().
z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(false).
Z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(true).

Usage:
$query->format('SELECT %1$n FROM %2$n WHERE %3$n = %4$a', 'foo', '#__foo', 'bar', 1);
Returns: SELECT `foo` FROM `#__foo` WHERE `bar` = 1

Notes:
The argument specifier is optional but recommended for clarity.
The argument index used for unspecified tokens is incremented only when used.

##### Signature

```php
public Joomla\Database\Mysql\MysqlQuery::format ( string $format  ) : string
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `format` | `string` | The formatting string. |

##### Return Values

`string` Returns a string produced according to the formatting string.

##### Errors/Exceptions

No errors or exceptions are thrown.

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.

```php
 * e - Escape: Replacement text is passed to $this->escape().
 * E - Escape (extra): Replacement text is passed to $this->escape() with true as the second argument.
 * n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
 * q - Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quote().
```

#### `Joomla\Database\DatabaseQuery::format`

Find and replace sprintf-like tokens in a format string.

Each token takes one of the following forms:
%%       - A literal percent character.
%[t]     - Where [t] is a type specifier.
%[n]$[x] - Where [n] is an argument specifier and [t] is a type specifier.

Types:
a - Numeric: Replacement text is coerced to a numeric type but not quoted or escaped.
e - Escape: Replacement text is passed to $this->escape().
E - Escape (extra): Replacement text is passed to $this->escape() with true as the second argument.
n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
q - Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quote().
Q - Quote (no escape): Replacement text is passed to $this->quote() with false as the second argument.
r - Raw: Replacement text is used as-is. (Be careful)

Date Types:
- Replacement text automatically quoted (use uppercase for Name Quote).
- Replacement text should be a string in date format or name of a date column.
y/Y - Year
m/M - Month
d/D - Day
h/H - Hour
i/I - Minute
s/S - Second

Invariable Types:
- Takes no argument.
- Argument index not incremented.
t - Replacement text is the result of $this->currentTimestamp().
z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(false).
Z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(true).

Usage:
$query->format('SELECT %1$n FROM %2$n WHERE %3$n = %4$a', 'foo', '#__foo', 'bar', 1);
Returns: SELECT `foo` FROM `#__foo` WHERE `bar` = 1

Notes:
The argument specifier is optional but recommended for clarity.
The argument index used for unspecified tokens is incremented only when used.

##### Signature

```php
public Joomla\Database\DatabaseQuery::format ( string $format  ) : string
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `format` | `string` | The formatting string. |

##### Return Values

`string` Returns a string produced according to the formatting string.

##### Errors/Exceptions

No errors or exceptions are thrown.

##### Examples

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.

```php
 * n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
```

#### `Joomla\Database\Sqlsrv\SqlsrvQuery::format`

Find and replace sprintf-like tokens in a format string.

Each token takes one of the following forms:
%%       - A literal percent character.
%[t]     - Where [t] is a type specifier.
%[n]$[x] - Where [n] is an argument specifier and [t] is a type specifier.

Types:
a - Numeric: Replacement text is coerced to a numeric type but not quoted or escaped.
e - Escape: Replacement text is passed to $this->escape().
E - Escape (extra): Replacement text is passed to $this->escape() with true as the second argument.
n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
q - Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quote().
Q - Quote (no escape): Replacement text is passed to $this->quote() with false as the second argument.
r - Raw: Replacement text is used as-is. (Be careful)

Date Types:
- Replacement text automatically quoted (use uppercase for Name Quote).
- Replacement text should be a string in date format or name of a date column.
y/Y - Year
m/M - Month
d/D - Day
h/H - Hour
i/I - Minute
s/S - Second

Invariable Types:
- Takes no argument.
- Argument index not incremented.
t - Replacement text is the result of $this->currentTimestamp().
z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(false).
Z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(true).

Usage:
$query->format('SELECT %1$n FROM %2$n WHERE %3$n = %4$a', 'foo', '#__foo', 'bar', 1);
Returns: SELECT `foo` FROM `#__foo` WHERE `bar` = 1

Notes:
The argument specifier is optional but recommended for clarity.
The argument index used for unspecified tokens is incremented only when used.

##### Signature

```php
public Joomla\Database\Sqlsrv\SqlsrvQuery::format ( string $format  ) : string
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `format` | `string` | The formatting string. |

##### Return Values

`string` Returns a string produced according to the formatting string.

##### Errors/Exceptions

No errors or exceptions are thrown.

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.

#### `Joomla\Database\Sqlsrv\SqlsrvDriver::getInstance`

Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.

There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.

Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.

#### `Joomla\Database\Mysqli\MysqliQuery::format`

Find and replace sprintf-like tokens in a format string.

Each token takes one of the following forms:
%%       - A literal percent character.
%[t]     - Where [t] is a type specifier.
%[n]$[x] - Where [n] is an argument specifier and [t] is a type specifier.

Types:
a - Numeric: Replacement text is coerced to a numeric type but not quoted or escaped.
e - Escape: Replacement text is passed to $this->escape().
E - Escape (extra): Replacement text is passed to $this->escape() with true as the second argument.
n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
q - Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quote().
Q - Quote (no escape): Replacement text is passed to $this->quote() with false as the second argument.
r - Raw: Replacement text is used as-is. (Be careful)

Date Types:
- Replacement text automatically quoted (use uppercase for Name Quote).
- Replacement text should be a string in date format or name of a date column.
y/Y - Year
m/M - Month
d/D - Day
h/H - Hour
i/I - Minute
s/S - Second

Invariable Types:
- Takes no argument.
- Argument index not incremented.
t - Replacement text is the result of $this->currentTimestamp().
z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(false).
Z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(true).

Usage:
$query->format('SELECT %1$n FROM %2$n WHERE %3$n = %4$a', 'foo', '#__foo', 'bar', 1);
Returns: SELECT `foo` FROM `#__foo` WHERE `bar` = 1

Notes:
The argument specifier is optional but recommended for clarity.
The argument index used for unspecified tokens is incremented only when used.

##### Signature

```php
public Joomla\Database\Mysqli\MysqliQuery::format ( string $format  ) : string
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `format` | `string` | The formatting string. |

##### Return Values

`string` Returns a string produced according to the formatting string.

##### Errors/Exceptions

No errors or exceptions are thrown.

##### Examples

#### `Joomla\Database\Mysqli\MysqliDriver::getInstance`

Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.

There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.

Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.

##### Signature

```php
public static Joomla\Database\Mysqli\MysqliDriver::getInstance ( [ array $options = [] ] ) : Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `options` | `array` | Parameters to be passed to the database driver. Defaults to `[]`. |

##### Return Values

`Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver` A database object.

##### Errors/Exceptions

Throws RuntimeException <br />

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.

```php
 * Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.
 *
 * There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
 * DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
 * be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.
 *
 * Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
 * passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.
 *
 * @param   array  $options  Parameters to be passed to the database driver.
 *
 * @return  DatabaseDriver  A database object.
 *
 * @since   1.0
 * @throws  \RuntimeException
 */
```

#### `Joomla\Database\Pgsql\PgsqlDriver::getInstance`

Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.

There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.

Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.

##### Signature

```php
public static Joomla\Database\Pgsql\PgsqlDriver::getInstance ( [ array $options = [] ] ) : Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `options` | `array` | Parameters to be passed to the database driver. Defaults to `[]`. |

##### Return Values

`Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver` A database object.

##### Errors/Exceptions

Throws RuntimeException <br />

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.
 
```php
/**
 * Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.
 *
 * There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
 * DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
 * be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.
 *
 * Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
 * passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.
 *
 * @param   array  $options  Parameters to be passed to the database driver.
 *
 * @return  DatabaseDriver  A database object.
 *
 * @since   1.0
```

#### `Joomla\Database\Pgsql\PgsqlQuery::format`

Find and replace sprintf-like tokens in a format string.

Each token takes one of the following forms:
%%       - A literal percent character.
%[t]     - Where [t] is a type specifier.
%[n]$[x] - Where [n] is an argument specifier and [t] is a type specifier.

Types:
a - Numeric: Replacement text is coerced to a numeric type but not quoted or escaped.
e - Escape: Replacement text is passed to $this->escape().
E - Escape (extra): Replacement text is passed to $this->escape() with true as the second argument.
n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
q - Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quote().
Q - Quote (no escape): Replacement text is passed to $this->quote() with false as the second argument.
r - Raw: Replacement text is used as-is. (Be careful)

Date Types:
- Replacement text automatically quoted (use uppercase for Name Quote).
- Replacement text should be a string in date format or name of a date column.
y/Y - Year
m/M - Month
d/D - Day
h/H - Hour
i/I - Minute
s/S - Second

Invariable Types:
- Takes no argument.
- Argument index not incremented.
t - Replacement text is the result of $this->currentTimestamp().
z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(false).
Z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(true).

Usage:
$query->format('SELECT %1$n FROM %2$n WHERE %3$n = %4$a', 'foo', '#__foo', 'bar', 1);
Returns: SELECT `foo` FROM `#__foo` WHERE `bar` = 1

Notes:
The argument specifier is optional but recommended for clarity.
The argument index used for unspecified tokens is incremented only when used.

```php
 * Find and replace sprintf-like tokens in a format string.
 * Each token takes one of the following forms:
 *     %%       - A literal percent character.
 *     %[t]     - Where [t] is a type specifier.
 *     %[n]$[x] - Where [n] is an argument specifier and [t] is a type specifier.
 *
 * Types:
 * a - Numeric: Replacement text is coerced to a numeric type but not quoted or escaped.
 * e - Escape: Replacement text is passed to $this->escape().
 * E - Escape (extra): Replacement text is passed to $this->escape() with true as the second argument.
 * n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
 * q - Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quote().
 * Q - Quote (no escape): Replacement text is passed to $this->quote() with false as the second argument.
 * r - Raw: Replacement text is used as-is. (Be careful)
 *
 * Date Types:
```

#### `Joomla\Database\Sqlite\SqliteQuery::format`

Find and replace sprintf-like tokens in a format string.

Each token takes one of the following forms:
%%       - A literal percent character.
%[t]     - Where [t] is a type specifier.
%[n]$[x] - Where [n] is an argument specifier and [t] is a type specifier.

Types:
a - Numeric: Replacement text is coerced to a numeric type but not quoted or escaped.
e - Escape: Replacement text is passed to $this->escape().
E - Escape (extra): Replacement text is passed to $this->escape() with true as the second argument.
n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
q - Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quote().
Q - Quote (no escape): Replacement text is passed to $this->quote() with false as the second argument.
r - Raw: Replacement text is used as-is. (Be careful)

Date Types:
- Replacement text automatically quoted (use uppercase for Name Quote).
- Replacement text should be a string in date format or name of a date column.
y/Y - Year
m/M - Month
d/D - Day
h/H - Hour
i/I - Minute
s/S - Second

Invariable Types:
- Takes no argument.
- Argument index not incremented.
t - Replacement text is the result of $this->currentTimestamp().
z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(false).
Z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(true).

Usage:
$query->format('SELECT %1$n FROM %2$n WHERE %3$n = %4$a', 'foo', '#__foo', 'bar', 1);
Returns: SELECT `foo` FROM `#__foo` WHERE `bar` = 1

Notes:
The argument specifier is optional but recommended for clarity.
The argument index used for unspecified tokens is incremented only when used.

##### Signature

```php
public Joomla\Database\Sqlite\SqliteQuery::format ( string $format  ) : string
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `format` | `string` | The formatting string. |

##### Return Values

`string` Returns a string produced according to the formatting string.

##### Errors/Exceptions

No errors or exceptions are thrown.

#### `Joomla\Database\Sqlite\SqliteDriver::getInstance`

Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.

There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.

Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.

##### Signature

```php
public static Joomla\Database\Sqlite\SqliteDriver::getInstance ( [ array $options = [] ] ) : Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `options` | `array` | Parameters to be passed to the database driver. Defaults to `[]`. |

##### Return Values

`Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver` A database object.

##### Errors/Exceptions

Throws RuntimeException <br />

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.

```php
 * Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.
 *
 * There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
 * DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
 * be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.
 *
 * Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
 * passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.
 *
 * @param   array  $options  Parameters to be passed to the database driver.
 *
 * @return  DatabaseDriver  A database object.
 *
 * @since   1.0
```

#### `Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver::getInstance`

Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.

There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.

Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.

##### Signature

```php
public static Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver::getInstance ( [ array $options = [] ] ) : Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `options` | `array` | Parameters to be passed to the database driver. Defaults to `[]`. |

##### Return Values

`Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver` A database object.

##### Errors/Exceptions

Throws RuntimeException <br />

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.
 
```php
/**
 * Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.
 *
 * There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
 * DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
 * be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.
 *
 * Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
 * passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.
 *
 * @param   array  $options  Parameters to be passed to the database driver.
 *
 * @return  DatabaseDriver  A database object.
 *
 * @since   1.0
```

#### `Joomla\Database\Sqlazure\SqlazureDriver::getInstance`

Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.

There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.

Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.

##### Signature

```php
public static Joomla\Database\Sqlazure\SqlazureDriver::getInstance ( [ array $options = [] ] ) : Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver
```
##### Parameters

| Parameter | Type | Description |
|----------|------|-------------|
| `options` | `array` | Parameters to be passed to the database driver. Defaults to `[]`. |

##### Return Values

`Joomla\Database\DatabaseDriver` A database object.

##### Errors/Exceptions

Throws RuntimeException <br />

##### Examples

##### Drop-In Adapter

The drop-in adapter has the same signature as the original  method,
but leverages the corresponding Laravel package behind the scene.
 
```php
/**
 * Return a DatabaseDriver instance based on the given options.
 *
 * There are three global options and then the rest are specific to the database driver.  The 'driver' option defines which
 * DatabaseDriver class is used for the connection -- the default is 'mysqli'.  The 'database' option determines which database is to
 * be used for the connection.  The 'select' option determines whether the connector should automatically select the chosen database.
 *
 * Instances are unique to the given options and new objects are only created when a unique options array is
 * passed into the method.  This ensures that we don't end up with unnecessary database connection resources.
 *
 * @param   array  $options  Parameters to be passed to the database driver.
 *
 * @return  DatabaseDriver  A database object.
 *
 * @since   1.0
```

#### `Joomla\Database\Sqlazure\SqlazureQuery::format`

Find and replace sprintf-like tokens in a format string.

Each token takes one of the following forms:
%%       - A literal percent character.
%[t]     - Where [t] is a type specifier.
%[n]$[x] - Where [n] is an argument specifier and [t] is a type specifier.

Types:
a - Numeric: Replacement text is coerced to a numeric type but not quoted or escaped.
e - Escape: Replacement text is passed to $this->escape().
E - Escape (extra): Replacement text is passed to $this->escape() with true as the second argument.
n - Name Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quoteName().
q - Quote: Replacement text is passed to $this->quote().
Q - Quote (no escape): Replacement text is passed to $this->quote() with false as the second argument.
r - Raw: Replacement text is used as-is. (Be careful)

Date Types:
- Replacement text automatically quoted (use uppercase for Name Quote).
- Replacement text should be a string in date format or name of a date column.
y/Y - Year
m/M - Month
d/D - Day
h/H - Hour
i/I - Minute
s/S - Second

Invariable Types:
- Takes no argument.
- Argument index not incremented.
t - Replacement text is the result of $this->currentTimestamp().
z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(false).
Z - Replacement text is the result of $this->nullDate(true).

Usage:
$query->format('SELECT %1$n FROM %2$n WHERE %3$n = %4$a', 'foo', '#__foo', 'bar', 1);
Returns: SELECT `foo` FROM `#__foo` WHERE `bar` = 1

Notes:
The argument specifier is optional but recommended for clarity.
The argument index used for unspecified tokens is incremented only when used.

##### Signature

```php
public Joomla\Database\Sqlazure\SqlazureQuery::format ( string $format  ) : string
```
